(The velocity fraction, v/c, is analogous to slope for rotations.) In that scheme, your matrix becomes:

( coshα sinhα )
( sinhα  coshα )

where
β = v/c = tanhα
γ = coshα
βγ = sinhα

This is just like a rotation matrix

( cosθ –sinθ )
( sinθ cosθ )

but with hyperbolic trig functions instead of circular ones; and without one of the sines being negative.
Note that, like a rotation matrix, the above matrix has determinant = 1; it is volume-preserving. This follows from the identity
cosh²α – sinh²α = 1

The advantage of using α's rather than velocities, is that, like angles in rotations, they add when combining transformations; v's, like slopes, do not.

Einstein's dismissal of absolute simultaneity relies upon his definition of simultaneity for two spatially separated clocks which assumes (rather than demonstrates) that absolute space does not exist. He assumes that absolute space does not exist because it isn't empirically detectable which is to presuppose verificationism. This is a problem because verificationism has since been universally rejected by philosophers. As Lawrence Sklar in "Time, Reality, and Relativity" writes: "Certainly the original arguments in favour of the relativistic viewpoint were rife with verificstionist presuppositions about meaning.."

This doesn't mean we reject relativity of course, rather what this means is that the rejection of absolute simultaneity is unwarranted. Moreover, the move from Einstein's original interpretation to Minkowski's, based upon the problems of having an ontology of 3D objects enduring through time but with no privileged reference frame is now unjustified, for one can hold to a neo-Lorentzian interpretation that says that there is a privileged reference frame (and hence absolute simultaneity) but that time dilation and length contradiction are just distortions of our measurement instruments.

It seems to be admitted by philosophers and physicists on both sides of the debate that the three interpretations of STR are empirically equivalent. And finally, cosmic time would seem to provide a sort of universal, privileged reference frame thus lending support to the neo-Lorentzian view.
